item.title: Vim file type specific settings
item.description: If you want to run some vim script for a specific file type, don't make an auto command, they get messy really quickly. Instead, you should use ftplugin.

item.title: Jump to function definition in vim
item.description: One of the features I miss from Sublime Text is the Goto Anything. In vim, by default, you have :e **/bit and then tab, and it gets annoying pretty quickly. Thankfully, there's fzf (with fzf.vim).

item.title: Vim Line Completion
item.description: Do you know what kind of completion this is? Line completion. It looks for every lines that starts with the same text (it doesn't take into consideration the indication), and completes it for you! Awesome right?

item.title: The confirm option
item.description:
This is probably one of my favorite option in VIM. Just add this to your .vimrc:

set confirm

item.title: DynamicOpen function
item.description: I really open my .vimrc often. Too often to have to type :e ~/.vimrc or :tabe ~/.vimrc every time. Here's little function that will open a file in a new tab if there isn't enough room for a new split, and, you guessed it, in a new vertical split if there is.

item.title: Rerun last command with bang
item.description: Put this code in your vimrc to re run the previous command but with the bang (!) by just typing :Please.

item.title: Silent command-line mapping
item.description: If you want to set a mapping to run something that is echoed into the command line (something starting with : or / for example) to not be displayed, you can use the special argument silent.
